its a lovely handmade game with living dev support. can only recomend it. i was in mission 3 of the campaign certainly softlocked, but i sent my savegame via discord to the dev and he showed me how to proceed . top service. the graphics and animations are verry lovely to look at and its a ton of fun if youre looking for a strategy game. you CAN do hostile missions but you dont need to if you decide to be a peaceful colonist. the campaign is so far really challenging. the fact is : i saw dozens of early acess games so far, every single one disapointed me in support, or releasing dlc¬¥s in early acess *cough* ARK scorched earth *cough* or even shut down after going live. Bought this and Re;Birth1 on the same day.Like the first Re;Birth, it is ADDICTING, and you'll find yourself wanting to play it over and over again with everything it has to offer.If you have the DLC sword, it does become a little easier to level up rather quickly, and it does come in handy with the Fortify Enemies plan enabled, and fighting Arfoire.If you're having trouble with the shares, make sure you acquire and unlock and enable the Coliseum plan. Sum-UpIn-depth analysis further down.üü© Prosüü• Cons- Excellent level design full of secondary areas, Easter eggs and secrets to discover.- Dynamic, weighty combat; the emphasis put on physics makes the action both functional and spectacular.- Good art direction that delivers several spectacular landscapes and locations.- Wide variety of enemies, weapons and situations that force different approaches.- Solid challenge level on Revolutionary difficulty and above, with competent enemy AI and a combat design that punishes carelessness.- Zone Patrol mode feels overall dispersive and rather frustrating in its design, with obscure objectives and a few debatable gameplay choices.- Chapter 3 of the Campaign is a work in progress, ‚Äúcoming soon‚Äù in the level selection list. Given that the story ends with a cliffhanger, It‚Äôs hard to understand the choice of calling ADACA a ‚Äú1.0 Version‚Äù with an entire chapter yet to be released.üü® Bugs & Issuesüîß Specs- A few sections can be bypassed in a non-intended way.- Rare issues with enemy save-states after loading a save.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:The main campaign took me about 4 hours to finish on Revolutionary (Very Hard) difficulty, taking extra time to explore for secrets and loot. After that Zone Patrol is available; it delivers some new content and lore, although it‚Äôs not clear if it has a proper ‚Äòend‚Äô - I spent 4 more hours in it but your mileage may greatly vary. I see no reason to replay either of these modes, since their content is mostly linear or repeated.Is it worth buying?Yes. The price of 21‚Ç¨ is worthwhile for this amount of content. I can definitely recommend buying without a discount for the stellar overall quality alone.Verdict: Very GoodRating Chart HereAn exceptionally well-crafted love letter that will hook you with its captivating locations, attention to detail and engaging gameplay. If we‚Äôll never have HL2 Ep.3, we can always have ADACA instead.Follow our Curator page, IndieGems for more detailed reviews.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2851074327In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingProtagonist Jessy Thorn is a felon who got sentenced to mandatory military service. After basic training, the cryogenic pod housing them malfunctions, keeping them in stasis for a great amount of time. A sketchy sawbones known only as Chops reanimates Jessy and heals them, throwing in a cybernetic arm for good measure too. Awakened on the surface of planet Adaca, you won‚Äôt have time to know much of what‚Äôs going on, since the police called an APB on you -  time to run.The entire story takes place on the planet, which became of prominent interest for various factions, including mercenary groups and cultists, due to the ‚ÄòExclusion Zone‚Äô; an anomalous area where the laws of physics and space-time don‚Äôt apply in the same way as other places, and said to house phenomenal sources of power. It‚Äôs apparent that Adaca suffered battles and struggles in the past, which also continue to the present day.ADACA blends direct narrative in the form of dialogues, documents and log files, with indirect storytelling that uses the environment as primer for the players to then interpret the events as they see fit. I wouldn‚Äôt say the story, characters or happenings are a masterpiece at any point, but ADACA does successfully convey the feelings of mystery, intrigue and struggle coherent with its setting.Exploration & PuzzlesIn the Campaign, you‚Äôll traverse linear levels that however have a good amount of secondary areas and secrets to find in a style similar to the one seen in the Half-Life series, to which ADACA is clearly heavily-inspired. Thanks to Jessy‚Äôs cyber-arm, equipped with a gravity gun, you‚Äôll be able to move most objects around and use them to reach other places, as a weapon, or place them in order to solve puzzles that often use physics as a focal point. There isn‚Äôt a huge amount of proper ‚Äòpuzzles‚Äô, rather ADACA proposes significant changes to the gameplay formula (for instance, sections without weapons, or focused on threat avoidance) to spice up the variety. Each of these sections is well-polished (minus a few), and breaks the main gameplay loop effectively.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2851074262Combat SystemFights play out in an FPS fashion, either alone or with the support of (mostly) immortal companions that act out of their own will. Jessy will carry three weapons: a sidearm and two main guns of any type, ranging from shotguns to grenade launchers, assault rifles and several more ‚Äòexotic‚Äô alien guns I can‚Äôt really classify in any genre. Fighting the mercenary, police, cultist or even anomalous forces feels engaging at all times due to several factors. Firstly, the environments feel dynamic thanks to the physics that animate everything from debris to enemy corpses. Secondly, enemy AI is particularly competent, fast, dead accurate (on harder difficulties) and has advanced behaviors like retreating to regroup, flanking, using grenades. Rushing and hustling will lead to a swift death, while careful positioning and wise use of assets will be keys to victory.The variety of foes is high, and keeps adding new threats or aggravating circumstances until the end of the campaign. An important part of combat is also your gravity gun, which can be used to steal weapons from enemy hands, throw props around for high damage, and pull out all sorts of stunts like picking up rockets in mid air to throw them back to their user - very fun indeed.Zone Patrol ModeThis standalone mode puts you in the shoes of a wholly-different protagonist enrolled in a PMC, with the duty of completing various missions for their contractors. Unlike the campaign, this mode proposes an open-world structure with a world divided in zones, some will be the same as the campaign, others worked or even new. The enemies encountered won‚Äôt differ, but spawn randomly in each area instead of being hand-placed. Your objectives will vary, but they will mostly be fetch quests that involve crossing many areas to find some vaguely-described object or person of interest.ZP introduces some new mechanics like a shop to improve your arsenal for each sortie, by finding artifacts on the surface, which can then be used as currency to buy new weapons, armor and upgrades. While this mechanic gives a sense of progression, it just bars you from the same weapons and accessories you already used in the campaign.First debatable decision: you can‚Äôt manually save, which is frustrating when you have to traverse enormous swathes of land to reach an objective and get killed in the process. Secondly, the random enemy spawns are tremendously unbalanced compared to the meager starting weapons you‚Äôll have. It evens out later on, alas the start is really painful.This mode tries to be a sort of ‚Äòhalf-roguelite‚Äô based on runs, a non-linear open world, and at the same time quest-driven but influenced by RNG. It feels like a mess overall, due to the dispersiveness and sheer obscurity of its goals. While it brings some unique weapons and locations to the table (not present in the campaign), it feels like generic filler most of the time. Perhaps finishing Chapter 3 for release instead of this half-baked shenanigan would have been wiser.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2851234681

Sum-UpIn-depth analysis further down.üü© Prosüü• Cons- Tactically-paced combat with a solid foundation, that rewards careful approaches and punishes rushing.- Very good weapon variety, with most guns handling and feeling different from one another.- Solid situational variety across missions keeps up the interest.- The visual design  feels immersive and detailed, with emphasis on collateral damage.- Terrible stealth that doesn‚Äôt work for how levels / enemy placements are designed, and doesn‚Äôt give any major advantage at any point.- The cover system is badly implemented and demolishes both balance and sense of realism.- Checkpoints aren‚Äôt kept if the game is closed, you‚Äôll have to restart that mission from scratch. Had a crash, or power went out? Tough luck.- Comically useless AI-controlled companions that will regularly shoot into walls, run around weirdly, and also can‚Äôt die because of story reasons.- Low-quality English translation, with numerous errors and weird phrasing across the board.üü® Bugs & Issuesüîß Specs- Unable to screenshot. F12 opens a debug menu, and rebinding the key doesn‚Äôt work either.- Random, severe FPS drops during fights, that may sometimes crash the game.- Major issues with pathfinding and AI behavior of both enemies and allies.- Difficulty resets to Normal after each death. If this is only visual or not, I couldn‚Äôt determine.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:It took me around 5 hours to complete REDSIDE on Hard difficulty. Each mission‚Äôs content is entirely linear, there‚Äôs no reason to replay once finished.Is it worth buying?Even with the convenient price point of 6,60‚Ç¨, I can‚Äôt recommend buying. The technical and game design issues make the experience frustrating and cumbersome most of the time. There are countless, significantly better top-down shooters you could invest your time into.Verdict: MediocreRating Chart HereDespite a promising realism-oriented foundation and some good ideas, REDSIDE ultimately falls into mediocrity because of its evident game design flaws, technical issues and generic story.Follow our Curator page, Summit Reviews, to see more high-quality reviews regularly.In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingYear 1996. In a (probably?) alternative reality, Finland is close to joining the still-standing Soviet Union because, and I quote, ‚Äúthe Finnish bourgeois class realized the beauty of comradeship in Communism‚Äù, thus massively altering the geopolitical balance. You‚Äôll be playing as various Soviet operatives in a selection of high-risk conflict zones, all of them linked by a common plot.REDSIDE will take you across half the world, from well-known conflict zones such as the Middle East to less-known heat spots like Zaire, other than also undercover operations in Europe. Each setting is well-diversified and there clearly was some degree of research to make places look believable. The situations you‚Äôll find yourself into are also plausible for the most part, even if there is some degree of infeasibility for the sake of the story.The story is not complex and rather straightforward: terrorist groups set up a potential supply line for weapons of mass destruction; find out who they are, dismantle the whole thing so that the Soviet Union is proven to be a first-rate world power in keeping order. Each character has some degree of personality and bits of backstory, although REDSIDE isn‚Äôt a story-focused game and most of the lore, dialogues will be related to the task at hand, operations and ROEs.  ExplorationLet‚Äôs start with the fact that each of REDSIDE‚Äôs levels is linear and follows a rigid structure: you‚Äôll be corralled through a determined path, with a more open world being only present in a specific mission. There won‚Äôt be a map to consult, however objective markers will guide you in most situations, and each zone isn‚Äôt complex enough to get lost in it anyway. As far as map design is concerned, REDSIDE does a good job. Despite the destructibility of many elements like crates, barrels, select buildings, vehicles and more, you won‚Äôt be able to plow your way through as you please ‚Äú√† la battlefield‚Äù - at most, you may tear down doors and windows. There isn‚Äôt really much to be found: no lore files, pickups or anything of value, apart from the occasional weapon crate or light switch to make some areas darker.Combat SystemThis is a title that emphasizes realism, careful pacing and positioning above all else in each and every fight. As well-trained your operative may be, you‚Äôre only human after all. This concept is conveyed well, with both you and enemies having a fast time-to-kill; headshots are a guaranteed death, as are random critical hits, most explosions - if you‚Äôre out of cover, at least. Cover is an important concept that allows your character to suddenly become the Man of Steel himself; stand near a large object such as a wall or a pile of sandbags to gain Full Cover, that will greatly reduce any damage sustained - smaller objects only provide Half Cover, while being in an open field will debuff you with the Exposed status, lowering your accuracy and making you take extra damage. On paper this concept is great, but it‚Äôs implemented horribly. The main issue is that cover is granted in all directions: have a house wall on your back, but they‚Äôre shooting you from the front where you have nothing? Doesn‚Äôt matter, full cover it is. I can‚Äôt understate how broken this becomes on more than a few occasions, makes no sense whatsoever. Enemies don‚Äôt seem to use cover or be influenced by this mechanic at all, same goes for your (immortal) teammates. The pathfinding of all NPCs is so bugged and horrendous anyway, that even if cover worked it wouldn‚Äôt do much good. In combat you‚Äôll be able to carry two weapons and six grenades: while the former have unlimited ammo, grenades are limited, and for good reason: they‚Äôre extremely powerful, able to be thrown above obstacles at ludicrous distances, with high AoE and enormous damage. Some weapons have special properties like being silenced or able to pierce walls: the former have heavily reduced damage and aren‚Äôt very useful, while the latter are overpowered, allowing you to stay inside buildings and shoot through walls as if you had wallhack (especially because you can still see outside while inside buildings).Stealth & VehiclesSome missions desperately try to promote and emphasize stealth, which works by putting yourself in either a dark area or in bushes that conceal your person. Enemies that see a body (you can‚Äôt move bodies, by the way), hear shots, see you or see a death will alert everyone else immediately, making them converge on your position. Generally enemies are placed close to each other or in a way that makes stealth unfeasible or impractical - just going guns blazing is faster, better and has no consequence whatsoever, apart from aggroing more enemies - you won‚Äôt lose because of it, maybe make your life harder (or easier, since more enemies are better than having to deal with this half-broken system).On rare occasions, vehicles such as armored cars, UAVs or mobile AA can be used to lay utter devastation upon enemy ranks. Heavily armored, with unlimited ammo and powerful weapons, these beasts will enable you to plow through anything with ease - although being reckless will get you killed all the same, eventually.

Sum-UpIn-depth analysis further down.Follow our Curator page, Summit Reviews, to see more high-quality reviews regularly.üü© Prosüü• Cons- Decent variety of enemy types and other threats.- I played it already, so you don‚Äôt have to.- Far too easy even on the hardest setting, due to massive balance issues and train wrecks in how the combat system is designed.- Marketed as a mix of Survival Horror and Action; has almost none of the elements that actually compose a Survival Horror [surprised pikachu face here].- Messy lore that not only sports cringy high-school freshman writing at the best of times, but turns out as a mumbo-jumbo of esoterics and ‚Äòmad science‚Äô that doesn‚Äôt make any sense.- Forgettable boss fights that almost never feel unique nor challenging (save for the final boss, to an extent).- Underwhelming, constrained exploration that is hindered by excessive linearity, lack of meaningful rewards and invisible walls aplenty.- Local co-op only in the current day and age. 2003 called and said it wants its netcode back. Steam Remote Play is a lagfest - don‚Äôt consider it as a viable option, trust me.üü® Bugs & Issuesüîß Specs- Several achievements don‚Äôt unlock correctly when the requirement is fulfilled.- In some instances it‚Äôs possible to go out of the map‚Äôs boundaries.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:It took me just around two hours to complete Enemy Remains (ER) on ‚ÄúHell‚Äù (Very Hard) difficulty, taking extra time to explore each area in full. The content offered is linear, I see no reason to replay once finished.Is it worth buying?No. Even if the budget price tag of 5‚Ç¨ is adequate for this amount of content, the outlined issues, no replay value and overall bad quality simply don‚Äôt make ER a game worth investing your time into.Verdict: TerribleRating Chart HereA forgettable mish-mash of top-down shooter with just a hint of survival horror. With lore that doesn‚Äôt go anywhere, broken balance and lackluster polishing, ER doesn‚Äôt shine in any way to make it worthwhile.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2848289804In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingAs in the best (worst?) horror b-movies, our unnamed protagonist survives a car accident in the middle of a forest, only to realize the nearby town is infested by all sorts of monsters, ranging from demons to bio-abominations. In a very plausible surge of courage, pistol in hand, he charges ahead slinging lead to whatever supernatural creature unfortunate enough to cross his path. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt know where I am, I don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going on, I only know I must kill‚Äù, as a wise man once said.ER takes place in an unspecified rural town of an unclear, probably made-up country (like Narnia, Serbia or something along those lines) where everything has clearly gone to hell. Between the various, colorful contaminants littering most areas, and the plentiful ritualistic symbols drawn all over, it appears soon enough that this peaceful location has transformed into a nightmare. While the environment ‚Äòdoes the job‚Äô at conveying a dark atmosphere, the low-quality writing of most files and descriptions found around the world degrades both immersion and worldbuilding. Don‚Äôt expect an involving or deep experience at any point, as far as story and lore are concerned.Exploration & PuzzlesBe it forests, lagoons, factories or subterranean bunkers, the gig is the same: you‚Äôll be wandering about largely linear levels (with a few more ‚Äòopen‚Äô exceptions), that prove restrictive even for a Shooter, let alone a Survival Horror (which ER isn‚Äôt). While there are some secondary, minimally-diverging paths to find - that often hold a couple resources like ammo or medkits - most levels will still feel like one-way paths without enough expansion, verticality or diversity to result interesting. There are very few proper secrets overall, and they aren‚Äôt such a big deal either - some ammo or healing again, just like that crate you found in a corner five minutes ago.There are a few simplistic puzzles that involve finding a switch to open a gate, rotate props in the correct positions, or activate devices in a certain order to make a boss vulnerable. None of them is particularly obscure, and generally they‚Äôre all quick to solve or deal with. In case the levels weren‚Äôt linear enough, there will be guidance arrows shining on the ground on several occasions as well.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2848290103Combat System & BossesMost areas come packed with reasonably-varied monsters that either are already present or spawn when a certain point is passed, or a specific action (like flipping a switch) is executed. You‚Äôll have a roster of ten total weapons at your disposal, progressively found around the levels, each of them using different ammo types, which are however abundantly present. Special mention to your pistol, which has unlimited bullets that can also travel beyond the screen and hit far-away enemies; this, alongside the generally low enemy speed and their lackluster intelligence, leads to a major issue. Most encounters can actually be cleared by simply backpedaling in a circle while spamming pistol rounds until everything is dead, while stationary enemies can be hit beyond their view range with ease. It feels like all foes are weak, fragile and don't pose much of a threat unless you manage to get cornered, which rarely happens due to their slowness - I never died to normal ones.The other weapons aside from the handgun often deal tremendous damage / DPS, and are best saved for bosses or the rarely-seen bigger hordes of normal mobs - you won‚Äôt even need them most of the time, despite there being enough ammo around to use them to your heart‚Äôs content if you want to. There‚Äôs a grand total of three bosses: one is a bigger copy-paste of a normal ranged enemy, the other is just a melee foe (slowly) chasing you, and the final boss is a stationary, glorified turret with extra steps to make it vulnerable. None of these fights feels epic, and while bosses do hurt a lot for a change, they can easily be kited around or baited into shooting into cover. They have low health compared to the damage most weapons do: a couple shots of powerful weapons like the grenade launcher will be all it takes to dispatch them.Equipment & ProgressionIn this ‚Äúsurvival horror‚Äù, you won‚Äôt even have an inventory to manage; all of your findings like ammo or medkits will automatically be added to your total, uncapped for first aid and capped for ammo. There‚Äôs nothing else to find besides these things and the new weapons themselves, which don‚Äôt require puzzles or special actions to be gained: you‚Äôll find more guns around this little town than in a military base. The other part of the progression is represented by a basic stat system that can be upgraded once your character levels up (you can‚Äôt even see the XP left to do so). You may invest points in Speed (as in movement), Healing (medkit usage speed, which always restores 100% of HP anyway, and can be used instantly while on the move already, making this attribute useless) and Accuracy, which greatly improves the Pistol and possibly other bullet-based firearms‚Äô damage: straight up the best investment. Another underwhelming aspect that doesn‚Äôt feel like a real improvement of your abilities or equipment most of the time.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2848290023

This caused me to be unable to progress.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:I was unable to complete FoN2 due to the above-mentioned bug. I obtained the best weapons and armors, with just a few areas left to clear in 56 hours. I can only assume 5-10 more hours would have been needed to finish. The content is entirely linear, there‚Äôs no reason whatsoever to replay.Is it worth buying?No. Even if the budget price of 13,29‚Ç¨ is more than fair for the amount of content delivered, its tedious evolution combined with the other issues makes this a title to avoid even for fans of the genre.Verdict: MediocreRating Chart HereFoN 2 somewhat improves upon its predecessor, but fundamental issues remain and drag it down once more, just not as badly as the first entry.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2844463304In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingAn average guy (or girl), as in -you-, gets transported to a far-away island after touching a mysterious altar that appears in the middle of a workshop (because who wouldn‚Äôt do that?). Soon enough, a ghost says that you happen to be in a world once governed by the ‚ÄòAncients‚Äô, that used the power of the Force of Nature to accomplish great things. Alas the magical stone has been split into various shards in a (yet) unclear way, and your only way to get back to your world is finding them all.Lore and story aren‚Äôt at all FoN‚Äôs focus. As you proceed, there will be other ghosts to talk with, that will tell you their (brief) stories, some info about the world, and how they came to be in their current situation. Other than that, there‚Äôs mention of Tablets to find in order to know more, but I was unable to find any, as there‚Äôs no clear explanation on how to do so or even where to look for them.Exploration & Resource GatheringThe world is divided in various biomes, each featuring its own roster of enemies, resources and unique conditions. For instance, you better invest in some poison resistance gear to better handle the Swamp, and it will be mandatory to have heat-resistant clothes to explore volcanic zones. Each area is fairly large and while resources do not respawn, there‚Äôs such a quantity of them that running out is unlikely - enemies can be respawned using a bed, but only if you want to. In terms of exploration, the main thing to do will be finding all the new resources upon entering a new area, and gathering them for processing at your base. There don‚Äôt seem to be tool requirements for doing so, but of course better tools will do the job much faster. There are no random events, special places to find, unique enemies or anything like that: every zone is ‚Äúplain‚Äù and same-y: no reason to explore the whole thing, just go straight to your objective instead.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2845267391Base Building & Crafting SystemThe base is where you‚Äôll spend most of your time. While buildable anywhere, the fast travel system and least danger make the initial island the best place for doing so. A grid-like system allows precise placement of buildings, facilities and so on, which can also be moved at will with minimal time waste. Gotta say, the organizational features are spot on. Unlocking new buildings, weapons and other recipes involves research, which itself needs processing numerous materials into byproducts (for example, ink requires eggs, ash and other stuff, each itself processed by other raw materials). If this system is fair enough at first, the permutations of processing steps eventually become overwhelming. Later-game structures, consumables and gear require literal hours spent running about the couple dozen different crafting stations you‚Äôll have by that point, each for specific things. While the initial Ghost, ‚ÄòWanderer‚Äô will keep crafting queues going while you‚Äôre away he‚Äôll do so slowly, plus the queues are at best three steps long, without the possibility of pre-planning longer ones. I can‚Äôt emphasize enough how tedious this becomes: imagine playing Factorio but having to do everything by hand in late-game, that‚Äôs how it feels.Combat System & BossesBiomes are chock-full of enemies, and exploring inevitably will lead to conflict. Foes award not only materials, but also XP that will eventually level your character up, enabling you to spend three SPs per level in passive and active abilities, most of which level-gated at first. Apart from a select few, most of such skills and later on spells prove underwhelming or downright useless. The fighting itself consists in auto-attacking enemies until each is dead, while triggering consumables such as food (and later on potions) to stay alive. Imagine playing an ARPG like Diablo, right, but without having all those fantastic skills to use, and having to auto-attack enemies for dozens of hours on end. Enemies are monotonous, changing in shape or size but rarely feeling unique: there‚Äôs always the melee one and the ranged one, without more specialized behaviors or patterns to distinguish them most of the time.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2845440571Side Mechanics & Hidden QuestsEach biome containing a boss inevitably will spawn a Ghost once the big bad guy is dealt with. It‚Äôs possible to ‚Äútame‚Äù these creatures. No matter the place, the required task always involves exploring every inch of the biome at hand, which means kicking an enormous amount of shovelware enemies,translating in tremendous amounts of food to stay alive. Is this worth it for some more crafting speed in the base? No, it‚Äôs not, and adds even more tedium to an already heart-stoppingly boring formula. Good thing I had Sons of Anarchy on my second display while playing this slog.

It‚Äôs good, but could‚Äôve been much better.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2842347012In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingYoung aspirant-engineer Shane lives in a time full of technological marvels, but also unforgiving beliefs. Dropped on a deserted island by his own father, he needs to overcome a decades-old process known as ‚ÄúThe Trial‚Äù in order to return to Gideon, a steampunk flying city, and be acclaimed as a true Engineer ready to give their all for the pursuit of the common good. There‚Äôs no middle ground: success or death.Most of HSK will take place on a couple of islands with minimal infrastructure, on which Shane and the other aspirants before him have attempted building improvised machines to return to the golden city. It‚Äôs common to find mementos of those who came before - alongside more than a few corpses. There‚Äôs a stark contrast in seeing these pristine islands scarred by Gideon‚Äôs trial infrastructure, now mostly left to decay. Each location is rich in detail, and the attentive observer will find many ‚Äòself-contained‚Äô tales related to each.The lore files, ranging from radio transmissions about the current turmoil brewing in Gideon, to ancient texts about folklore and art - things mostly forgotten in the current era - are all written consistently well. More than a few will pique the reader‚Äôs interest, making them think there‚Äôs more than meets the eye on these islands, and that occult forces may be at work. Unfortunately, on many of such topics HSK stops elaborating soon enough, or doesn‚Äôt at all, in what seems like cutting corners as the campaign goes on.Exploration & PlatformingYour primary activity will be running around the current island in the search of anything useful to proceed towards Gideon. For this purpose, blueprints will often be placed in major locations, easy to find, and they‚Äôll tell you exactly what you need to do in order to restore the current unfinished machine, in the hopes it will be enough to complete the mission. Usually, this is a multi-step process that involves finding components all over a larger area that you can explore in an open.world fashion, thus leaving space to optional findings and collectibles, should you care about those.There are several platforming sections of jumping, sliding and climbing, rather simple overall, that act as a nice break in the ‚Äòwalking simulator‚Äô pacing and give some more action to the gameplay. Should you splat from a high place or get impaled, don‚Äôt worry, you‚Äôll restart from one of the plentiful auto-checkpoints placed around, without much progress loss.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2842346789PuzzlesAs a soon-to-be engineer, problem-solving should be a primary skill, that‚Äôs why the trial islands have been purposefully designed in a way that encourages such a process. In your journey, you‚Äôll come across half-finished pieces of machinery, sealed gates, generators in need of new batteries and more. Each of these situations will require you to figure out the correct order of doing things, like operating a crane to move parts in the correct places, or diving underwater to activate switches, other than figuring out codes to open many locks barring your path. None of these puzzles will be overly-difficult, but some are designed in a rather counter-intuitive way.Assembling machinery is much simpler than you‚Äôd think, with Shane doing most of the work automatically, with simple button prompts as commands. It would‚Äôve been more exciting to try and fail a few times just like a real engineer would while assembling experimental creations, alas it wasn‚Äôt so.Optional AreasThe islands house many a secret for those willing to look. Those who came before didn‚Äôt always ruish like mad to return to Gideon, in fact some developed other interests that will be clear enough when visiting what remains of their avenues. Books, messages, transmissions and even scrawling on the walls will each reveal a bit more about the various aspirants that came before, their choices, and eventually what led to their demise. Here HSK delves into topics like the occult, the paranormal and also freedom of choice about one‚Äôs pursuits. While the idea behind this premise is good, the narrative never pushes it enough to make it relevant compared to the main goal. These optional areas also may house collectibles and Keys, useful to open chests or locks that may be in wholly other parts, and often lead to significant lore revelations or hidden areas.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2841986474MinigamesA few minigames are available to further break the otherwise linear gameplay pacing. One of them consists in playing a guitar with a series of tunes that can be combined to play specific songs eventually found in the various notes and books you‚Äôll discover. One of them supposedly even leads to a secret ending, but I wasn‚Äôt able to figure it out. Another minigame is about assembling machines, with Shane welding, stapling and nailing bits and bobs in order to make whatever piece of junk work - somehow.

There isn‚Äôt enough replayability to warrant doing so at all.- Even if worthwhile, the optional content often proves dull and acts as filler to inflate the campaign's length in a cheap way.- Intergrade‚Äôs story goes on until the party leaves Midgar for good, which is about 35% of the total. This isn‚Äôt a complete remake, as the devs decided to split the whole thing in three instances, for whatever reason, instead of doing everything in the same game.üü® Bugs & Issuesüîß Specs- Occasional stuttering and frame-rate drops, even on a machine that exceeds recommended specs.- Hard difficulty is locked behind beating the game once.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:It took me 46 hours to complete the story on Normal, while also clearing all secondary content. After that, NG+ mode with some additional battles / bosses, and spin-off episode ‚ÄúIntermission‚Äù offer more content. Despite that, the game is largely linear and I don‚Äôt see a reason to replay it once cleared, as the NG+ content doesn‚Äôt warrant going through mostly the same stuff again.Is it worth buying?Yes, but not for the staggering base price of 80‚Ç¨. Even with the overall solid quality and content amounts, I suggest waiting for at least a 30% discount even to the most hardcore fans, to get value for your money.Verdict: Very GoodRating Chart HereAn overall impressive remake, but not without issues. Fans of the series will rejoice in experiencing its expanded lore and story, but also get bored by the excessive filler.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2835932186In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingThe city of Midgar stands as a shining beacon of technology in an otherwise desolate wasteland, using the all-powerful Mako energy to maintain its modern standards of living. Shinra Corporation de-facto rules above all, being the ones that built and maintained the reactors. Turns out using the planet‚Äôs vital energy as fuel isn‚Äôt the best choice long-term, so a group of ‚Äòeco-terrorists‚Äô called Avalanche wants to put a stop to Shinra‚Äôs ambitions by destroying the whole shebang. Protagonist Cloud Strife, ex-Shinra elite now turned rogue, is hired by the insurgents to help them fight the power - that‚Äôs how your story begins.This remake not only expands upon the original characters, but introduces many all-new ones, each with their own backstory. Generally speaking, they‚Äôre interesting enough and add to the story in a good way, with personalities distinct and remarkable enough to not feel generic. Between item descriptions, enemy files and lore entries, there‚Äôs a good amount of optional info about the world for those interested, personally I found this aspect interesting, as much of it wasn‚Äôt elaborated upon in the original FFVII.Exploration & Level DesignUntil late-game the levels will be largely linear, with just a few side-areas to explore for loot and some ‚Äòopen‚Äô areas that act as containers for side-quest-giving NPCs. Later on, fast-travel between various sectors becomes available, allowing you to finish eventual leftover quests and explore each area accurately at will - not much to find, though, as far as secrets go. Vendors are available in some places in the form of machines or actual people, who will sell you new weapons, unique accessories, Materia, and sometimes give you quests and minigames  to earn trinkets or other stuff not obtainable in any other way.The ‚Äòrandom encounters‚Äô with enemies have been reworked into seamless transitions between battle and exploration, that you can also skip by simply running away in many cases - a welcome addition. It‚Äôs annoying that many sections have scripted sequences where characters move at a deliberately slower pace, in most cases adding tedium instead of scenic buildup.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2835932350Combat SystemInstead of the turn-based system of the original VII, this remake opts for real-time battles where you control one character at time, while the other two are left to the AI, though you can switch between them at any time. Hitting enemies with basic attacks will fill your ATB gauge, essential to use spells, abilities, items and pretty much do anything else - your companions will behave competently while in the hands of the computer, but won‚Äôt use higher skills unless you switch and order them directly - mostly, they‚Äôll just stand there and soak up damage, or attack enemies when appropriate.The combat mechanics have been expanded upon, now featuring ‚ÄòStagger‚Äô and ‚ÄòPressure‚Äô effects, both critical to winning battles; deal great damage in a short time, and enemies will progressively build up stagger, making them extremely vulnerable for a short time - a circumstance that can also be triggered by targeting weak points or other specific actions unique to each enemy. For the rest, expect abilities, spells and items as in any JRPG, with particular emphasis on elemental weaknesses and status effect dispelling as keys to winning the more demanding fights. Summons are also a thing, but only in specific battles, and work as temporary NPCs you can‚Äô√¨t control directly, but spend ATB to trigger their abilities instead.Special mention for bosses, which prove elaborate and unique at all times, not to mention challenging and full of interesting mechanics that break the canons of battle, forcing you to get creative. The only critique I would make to bosses is that they won‚Äôt allow you to fully go through a well-planned combo if their health goes low enough, thus triggering a cutscene and resetting their status immediately, even while staggered or otherwise incapacitated.Character Management & ProgressionCompleting quests and killing mobs will credit you EXP, AP and SP. Now, these ‚Äòcurrencies‚Äô of sorts can be used to respectively increase character levels, something that happens automatically, level-up equipped Materia (also automatic) and enhance weapons, since each of them has its own skill tree of passive abilities, and is generally better-suited for different roles. Not only that, but each new weapon comes with a unique signature ability you can ‚Äòmaster‚Äô and permanently learn as a skill. Think of Materia as swappable abilities you can slot in weapons and accessories, to build your characters for the roles you prefer - only equipped materia will level up, thus unlocking new proprieties or stronger spell versions, so make sure you focus on what you really need as it‚Äôs impossible to get everything maxed out in one playthrough, unless you do a hell of a lot of grinding. https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2838803345

Each room is interesting to unlock and explore‚Ä¶ the first time, at least.- Decent replay value thanks to multiple endings and different possible paths to take.- Logical environmental interaction that plays out in a plausible way using the items at hand.- Tremendously unfair death-related mechanics designed to kill in ways you can‚Äôt possibly anticipate the first time. This creates ‚Äòfiller content‚Äô via backtracking, since the world resets on each death.- Generic storyline, mediocre writing of lore documents. Nothing feels original or interesting at any point, the decent premise devolves into ‚Äòyet another horror‚Äô very quickly.- Obnoxious voiced protagonist, who speaks the same lines endlessly and describes items in a flat, irritating, out-of-place tone that completely ruins the atmosphere.- Poor MKB support. Mouse usage is limited to aiming / looking around, all menus need to be navigated with Arrow Keys or WASD without key rebinding. Unacceptable for a 2022 PC release.- Inability to discard / delete unwanted or useless items: you‚Äôll have to run back at a stash each time, or use an item if possible, to make room.üü® Bugs & Issuesüîß Specs- Some distortion effects, like film grain or film bands, can‚Äôt be turned off.- Enemies can spawn very close to transitions / doors, and become a guaranteed damage source you can‚Äôt avoid in time.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:It took me around 4 hours to get one of the endings. Playtime may vary greatly depending on number of deaths (resets). Replay value is decent: depending on certain actions and the number of deaths you will unlock different endings and situations, however most of the game will remain the same nonetheless.Is it worth buying?No. Not only the price tag of 20‚Ç¨ is rather steep for 4 hours plus additional runs (that will take much less, given your acquired knowledge), but the outlined issues deal a severe blow to any and all enjoyment. Move on to better survival horrors, there‚Äôs plenty around.Verdict: BadRating Chart HereA poorly-executed survival horror that relies on annoying mechanics to stretch content, alongside an obnoxious protagonist and a forgettable story.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2832333700In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingNaked and terrified, you‚Äôll wake up in a bathtub full of bloodied water. You don‚Äôt have the slightest idea of what happened, and now you‚Äôre locked in a motel bathroom. After getting your bearings and finding a way out, you‚Äôll soon understand things aren‚Äôt alright at all in this decrepit, half-totaled motel, between unearthly screams and horrendous abominations that roam the locales.Most of Oxide is set in a three-story motel under renovation. The horror feeling is kinda there, with most premises being dark, damp, foggy and eerie, as well compounded by an audio compartment that does the job well enough. Too bad this is all ruined by Matt (as in, you) constantly stating ‚Äúhe needs to get out‚Äù, or describing events / items with a tone as robotic as a train station‚Äôs automated announcer. Some classic ‚Äòcheap jumpscares‚Äô are added to the mix at times, and they fail to impress.Numerous lore documents pertaining to yourself, or other relevant characters, can be found in the furniture, on the ground and generally all over the place. Each of the writers is distinct enough in their tone, however the content itself feels quite clich√®d and just doesn‚Äôt hook you the right way at any point. ‚ÄúMad scientist doing crazy experiments‚Äù trope? Check! ‚ÄúGuy who lost humanity and now is on a vengeance‚Äù? Sure! ‚ÄúToken female character that doesn‚Äôt know what the hell to do‚Äù? Yep! Horror tropes 101, everyone.Exploration & PuzzlesYour primary goal will be opening as many rooms as you can, in the hopes of finding a way to the third floor‚Äôs common areas, the only exit still available. Think of each room as a self-contained mini-puzzle, as most of them will have one or more items to interact with, that often require you figuring out a specific item order, a code, or the right item to use between several. There is always a right way and several wrong ways to get something done, the latter ones often inflicting you a detrimental status effect, or killing you instantly in a few cases.The main issue is that in many instances, not only is there no clear way to figure out what‚Äôs right or wrong, but you‚Äôll also be actively deceived by Oxide itself. For example, I found the number ‚Äú15‚Äù behind a closet, and said to myself ‚Äúthat must be the correct vial, among five, i have to pick for this puzzle!‚Äù - nope, I got poisoned and died instead. Expect this to happen numerous times, and if you ran out of supplies, well‚Ä¶ goodbye!Exploring the premises will indeed net you a modest number of consumables, like bandages or antidotes, vital to clear the effects that otherwise become lethal in around 30-40 seconds or so. Even by collecting all of them, there‚Äôll be no way in Hell you‚Äôll be able to get out alive on your first run: too many shenanigans you can‚Äôt predict.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2832658783Combat & Inventory ManagementYour trusty revolver will be the only means of defense against the horrors. Bullets are a fairly common finding, and most enemies take five to vanquish. It's a simple point-and-shoot affair, with a small quick time event to free yourself from an enemy‚Äôs grab, and no other particular mechanic, since all except one enemy are static threats. It has to be noted enemies have a detection system, some of them can be ‚Äòstealthed‚Äô but this is inconsistent - most will just spawn and target you immediately after certain interactions, though.Up to nine inventory slots can be gained, via some items found in the various rooms. This is very limited compared to the amount of  unique stuff you‚Äôll find (like keys), but the shared stashes alleviate part of the issue by letting you deposit items for later use, and retrieve them at any time. And yet, expect to backtrack back and forth numerous times for this.Death-related MechanicsSo, what happens exactly when you die? Don‚Äôt worry, I'll now explain to you the peak of game design we have to deal with here. Upon your demise, a story-related cutscene will play, different each time, and you‚Äôll be back to square one at the bathtub. Everything has been reset: stash, inventory, upgrades, doors are locked again. Some things changed, though: certain enemy spawn have been altered, and on later deaths more foes will spawn, like poison plants. Most item spawns remain the same, except for a very few that change slightly. This would be fine and interesting if implemented properly - not the case here.The thing is, nothing major changes with death, apart from more enemies to deal with and the ending you‚Äôll get. You‚Äôll have to do the exact same things again twice, thrice, etc. - each time with added annoyances. This becomes tedious, boring very soon, and given the game kills you in unpredictable ways as explained before, this creates a perfect storm of frustration. Don‚Äôt think of this as ‚Äòold school‚Äô because it isn‚Äôt, it‚Äôs simply badly designed.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2832658863

Framerate drops, occasional stuttering and scorching temperatures will be normal even on high-end machines far above the requirements.- Inconsistent voice acting. Some characters‚Äô way of speaking feels flat, starkly contrasted with the eventual situations of urgency, fear or danger they‚Äôre involved in.üü® Bugs & Issuesüîß Specs- In rare cases, some interactions may get stuck forever. Load a saved game to fix.- Players may end up outside the map in a certain location.- Some secondary choices may not account correctly for consequence in specific cases.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:It took me around 9 hours to complete Martha is Dead (MiD), taking extra time to clear what secondary content I managed to find, and explore all locations accurately. The content is entirely linear, there‚Äôs no reason to replay once finished.Is it worth buying?The standard price of 30‚Ç¨ (3‚Ç¨ / hour of playtime) is still a bit steep for this amount of content, despite the good quality offered. I‚Äôd recommend waiting for a small discount before buying.Verdict: Very GoodRating Chart HereA high-quality narrative adventure with a setting that proves novel, historically-accurate and interesting. Some moderate issues prevent it from realizing its full potential.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2830781616In-DepthPremise, Setting & Writing1944. Italy is ravaged by the misery of war, with Allied forces moving up towards the Tuscany region while Axis troops mount a desperate defense. Protagonist Giulia K. is the daughter of a high-profile Nazi officer, but even this privileged position doesn‚Äôt save her from tragedy. One day, her twin sister Martha is found dead in a lake - an overwhelming loss. She always was her parents‚Äô favorite, unlike Giulia, so the latter decides to take her identity, pretending to be her from that moment forward, to gain the love so far denied to her.MiD mostly takes place in and around a countryside villa outside the village of San Casciano, Tuscany. There‚Äôs a remarkable attention to detail in the realization of each location, from the interiors of a typical upper-class 1940 Italian household, with luxuries such as electric power and a phone line, to the verdant woods and sun-beaten dirt paths commonly seen in the rural areas of the region even today. The marked contrast between these idyllic landscapes and the brutality of war, or the horrifying visions in Giulia‚Äôs mind, creates a rollercoaster of varied atmospheres that works out very well.Apart from the protagonist, there‚Äôs a small roster of relevant characters that, however, never happen to dialogue directly with you at any point: a consequence of the recent events, and of the pretense Giulia decided to put up. You‚Äôll hear conversations, read missives, listen to telephone calls, but never engage in active dialogues save for some phone calls at specific points. The writing feels plausible, with an Italian voiceover that accounts for the different mannerisms and speech patterns of the time. Most situations feel plausible and realistic, even if (probably by design) you‚Äôll end up questioning the veracity of some of them as the game progresses. Exploration & InvestigationThe story plays out through a number of days, each having a primary objective related to the events at hand, and a series of optional activities as well. Generally, you‚Äôll be able to explore the world freely at any time, with the primary areas being the villa and its courtyard, the nearby forest and the lake. Some places will be locked until specific events happen, or certain quests are triggered by your findings. Your trusty camera will be of paramount importance, as it will not only allow you to collect evidence in order to shed light on your sister‚Äôs death, but also to use filters (such as infrared) to reveal the unseen. There are a vast number of interactable objects that reveal more about the family‚Äôs past, the general lore or the people related to you in some way, each of them is voice-narrated by Giulia. Those looking to do everything will find much information in these optional interactions, they‚Äôre definitely worth the extra time spent.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2831372692Secondary QuestsWhile your focus remains finding the truth about Martha‚Äôs death, there will be other things to do as well. For instance, hidden riddles can be found by photographing specific objects in the world, optional points of interest that reveal dark stories, or trigger quests altogether. These missions may be optional, but contain a good chunk of unique content, such as puzzles, minigames and sub-storylines regarding parallel ongoing events. Some of these elements also can be missed, since the game progresses in a series of days alongside the main quest‚Äôs evolution: after certain events unfold, some areas may not be accessible anymore, thus locking the quests out forever (unless you reload an earlier save). Going just for the main story is something I wouldn‚Äôt recommend, as these secondary missions, even if a tad annoying in pacing at times, prove overall interesting and expand on the narrative considerablyPuzzles & MinigamesThe most frequent type of puzzle will be associated with photography: relevant items to frame, both primary and secondary, will be highlighted on your HUD, and it will be up to you to use the right camera accessories, such as filters, and set the right zoom level, exposure and focus to get the perfect shot. Not only that, but photos also need to be developed in a dark room, which involves a simple button-pressing prompt as QTE. Other than that, you‚Äôll eventually be decoding telegraph ciphers, finding items such as keys to unlock doors, boxes and passages containing critical items, or figure out the right things to say in a phone call to extract information. There are also a few quick-time events here and there, but they‚Äôre fairly simple and not demanding in skill or reflexes at all, in line with the genre‚Äôs expectations.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2830781865

Sum-UpIn-depth analysis further down.Follow our Curator page, Summit Reviews, to see more high-quality reviews regularly.üü© Prosüü• Cons- Some clever combat mechanics that prove interesting to use, give the system uniqueness to an extent.- Wide variety of enemies with unique movesets, quirks and abilities.- Good art direction: each area feels unique and well-constructed visually.- Serious balance issues with weapon classes and builds. Ranged is OP, 2H is just a DPS downgrade compared to anything else, Dual has a horrendous moveset, 1H / Shield is just plain.- Mechanically shallow. Many features customary to the Souls genre are emaciated or downright absent; this makes progression, combat and build-crafting too simplistic.- Story, lore and characters feel insipid and cliched. It never hooks you at any point, leaves a sour aftertaste once the credits roll.- Boring level design, that results way too linear for the genre, with only two ‚Äúhidden‚Äù optional areas in total, and nothing else of interest to find or get excited for at any point.- Disappointing co-op system design: not only does it require random consumable drops to function, but is also restricted to bosses only.üü® Bugs & Issuesüîß Specs- Unreliable hit detection with certain enemies or weapon move sets.- RTX makes little visual difference in general, and isn‚Äôt worth using.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:Took me around 12 hours to clear a run (logged 15h ‚Äòcause I restarted once early on), while taking time to explore all locations accurately. There is some replay value in experimenting with a different build (which isn‚Äôt gonna be a totally different experience, unlike in some other Souls), everything else stays the same.Is it worth buying?No. The price of 40‚Ç¨ is way too steep for this amount of content, features and quality -  even discounted, this will always be a mediocre title. There are other sci-fi souls (Surge 1-2, Shattered to name some) much better than this for the same or lower cost.Verdict: MediocreRating Chart HereA subpar attempt at Indie Souls-like. Ultimately DOLMEN feels generic, uninspired, simplistic and devoid of any polishing despite some genuinely interesting ideas. Genre veterans may have some fun with it, but it‚Äôs objectively not a good title.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2828724614In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingRevion Prime was just another anonymous planet under Zoan control (your faction, by the way), until the powerful DOLMEN Crystals were discovered on it. Some scientists got their hands full, started experimenting with trans-dimensional technology, and made a real mess of things - on top of other factions wanting a slice of the cake. Guess who has to clean up the mess?If the classic trope of ‚Äúsomeone fiddled with stuff they couldn‚Äôt comprehend and screwed up reality‚Äù sounds clich√®, that‚Äôs because it is. Despite locales actually feeling diverse and reasonably well-designed, at no point the narrative premise evolves past ‚Äúbash everyone in your way to get the damn crystals‚Äù or has any memorable character. We have the power-tripped supervillain, the zero-charm protagonist that says probably five lines in the entire game, the generic utilitarian radio operator, and a slew of NPCs with the personality of a rusted wheelbarrow, that have no quests or backstories whatsoever. Not even the optional lore files salvage it, as they never really prove interesting.ExplorationDOLMEN plays out as a classic souls-like in this part, meaning you‚Äôll be roaming various locales crawling with enemies, look out for the occasional item to collect, and most importantly activate Beacons (bonfires), which allow you to restore HP and Batteries (Estus), but also respawn enemies. Beacons also allow you to fast-travel between each, and teleport to your ship which contains crafting, cosmetic and leveling-up facilities, plus a totally useless NPC that just stands there staring at you menacingly.Don‚Äôt expect a complex level layout with exciting secrets and mind-bending verticality or hidden shortcuts: most levels are linear, with just a couple exceptions - most don‚Äôt even have any real shortcut or looping design at all. The only reasons to explore are crates with crafting materials, hidden NPCs that grant unique parts and lore files, but that‚Äôs all rather easy to find.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2828761665Combat System & BossesBread and butter of the experience, the combat here has some good ideas, admittedly. First of all, healing doesn‚Äôt work as you may be accustomed to for this genre. Energy (as in, Mana) acts as your healing medium, and can only be recharged with Batteries, coming in limited amounts and restored at Beacons - Estus Flask with extra steps. Mana also is used for Energy Mode, which is an amped-up status you can trigger at any time, that gives elemental powers to your attacks, other than also for ranged weapons and eventual weapon-specific abilities.The way elemental effects are handled is pretty good, as when enemies with one of the three status effects (Frozen, Burning, Poisoned) are hit with a weapon of that same element, this triggers powerful passive effects that deal significant amounts of damage - debuff first, hit second, that‚Äôs the way to go. This is a smart system that could have been built upon, but sadly it wasn‚Äôt so.Now onto the issues. The main issue with combat is the jank, with fiddly animations and mechanics that are about as reliable as that used car you bought last month from that shady salesman. What is customary in the genre just isn‚Äôt there: backstabs, ripostes, spells, stat-boosting consumables - all of this simply isn‚Äôt accounted for, making combat feel shallow not after long. The balance is all over the place really, with ranged easily overpowering everything else, alongside a fast melee as side to exploit elemental effects while energy recharges. Boss design feels average at best, with none of the fights really feeling epic despite their evolving movesets and sometimes considerable difficulty.Progression & CraftingEnemies and breakable elements drop crafting materials that can be used at the ship‚Äôs printer to craft progressively better weapons and armors, each with stat requirements to be used, of course. Each armor and weapon will contribute towards a certain Technology (Zoan, Driller, Revian) with passive abilities to match, think of it as a ‚Äòset bonus‚Äô of sorts. Crafted items can be further enhanced with Epic and Rare materials which give them better stats compared to the ‚Äúregular‚Äù versions. Unless you want to craft boss weapons, which require you to kill each boss three times (respawning them costs crystals with low drop rate), the rest of the materials will come along without particular grinding in general. You can use Nanites (souls) to improve your character stats permanently in the ship pod, and this works like in any other Souls game.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2828036749Multiplayer SystemYou can attempt bosses in jolly cooperation with your fellow DOLMEN players, using a beacon near each arena. The design of this is dement however, as it requires consumable, low-drop resources you can lose on death to be activated, no refunds in case you lose. Whoever thought gating multiplayer behind resource grinding was a good idea, didn‚Äôt think straight at all.

Sum-UpIn-depth analysis further down.Follow our Curator page, Summit Reviews, to see more high-quality reviews regularly.üü© Prosüü• Cons- Impressive simulation accuracy: physics, vacuum, cutting mechanics and all the hazards are recreated incredibly well; they contribute to a realistic experience.- Good number of ship variants that become increasingly complex and dangerous.- Compelling progression system, with upgrades that consistently feel like a real improvement.- A gameplay system that rewards precision, method, planning ahead and heavily punishes rushing / not learning the mechanics properly.- Above-average soundtrack quality, with some really neat tracks in it.- Clich√®d story with largely uninspired characters and boring dialogues. It doesn‚Äôt hook you at any point, and has few (if any) gripping moments.- In some phases, it‚Äôs unclear what needs to be done to make the main story progress: this can lead to wasted time and some frustration.üü® Bugs & Issuesüîß Specs- In some cases, the story may not progress at the intended time. Restart the game to fix.- Significant frame rate drops (from 60 to 30-40) on some larger ship models, even on good hardware.- Some materials / components are color coded the wrong way in the scanner.- 3900X- 2080Ti- 32GB RAM- SSD- 1440pContent & Replay Value:It took me 32 hours to complete Hardspace Shipbreaker (HSB) in Standard mode, and also unlock all the achievements. The campaign is linear, without choices, and ship models will start being always the same after a while; I see no reason to keep going after that, since you‚Äôll have seen it all by then. There is no reason to replay, either.Is it worth buying?The 35‚Ç¨ tag is fair for this amount of content and especially quality. I can definitely recommend a full-price purchase.Verdict: Very GoodRating Chart HereA brilliant sci-fi sandbox puzzle that manages to create a fresh gameplay formula. It‚Äôs a pity the story can‚Äôt be up to par with the other excellent elements.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2826400797In-DepthPremise, Setting & WritingStory-wise, HSB starts off with a not-so-novel premise: humanity became a space-faring civilization de-facto controlled by megacorporations, with alliances and governments losing more control as time passes. LYNX is the biggest fish of them all, having pioneered modern space travel, thus amassing ludicrous amounts of power and resources. That‚Äôs who you‚Äôll be working for as a shipbreaker, tasked with dismantling decommissioned vessels for the recycling market. The game pushes heavily on the themes of ethical treatment of workers and sustainability of employment. Your shipbreaking career will be contourned not only by the stories of your colleagues, each shedding more light on the grim state of humanity and on LYNX‚Äôs dehumanizing practices, but also reinforced by dozens of data recordings found in derelict ships. From your cramped living quarters to the overly-lawyered contracts and documents piling up in your inbox, the corporate dystopia seems all too real.Shipbreaking OperationsMost of your time will be spent in the shipyard, pulling apart vessels large and small to net LYNX a big stack of cash, in shifts lasting 15 minutes each (you can dedicate multiple shifts to the same ship, don‚Äôt worry). Each ship is made of the most diverse materials and appliances depending on its role (cargo, scientific, military‚Ä¶) but it all boils down to one thing: sorting the right stuff into the right ‚Äòbin‚Äô (either furnace, processor or barge) with most things being color-coded on your scanner for this purpose.You‚Äôll have three tools for this job: the cutter, able to slice through low-density materials, vaporize walls, provide access to sealed compartments: your number one ally in dismantling things correctly. Then you have the ‚Äògravity gun‚Äô, able to move heavy objects for you to push into the right bin, and later on create Tethers, that essentially act as self-pulling ropes to haul ship parts too big for you to handle. The last tool are demo charges, able to cut entire ships in half in a matter of seconds, but at the cost of risking damage to sensitive equipment, explosions, fire hazards - use their power wisely, and only as last resort. The passive scanner highlights objects and sorts them by purpose and color, so that you know what‚Äôs what without too much hassle.The amount of perfection in how destruction, physics, explosive decompressions, fires are all recreated is great, even in failure there is some kind of strange pleasure, in seeing a ship blown in literally hundreds of smithereens flying everywhere, or the mess left inside after a decompression gone wrong.If this sounds simple enough, you‚Äôll quickly realize it isn‚Äôt. Accidents happen - often: from a small fire burning a couple of cargo crates to a critical reactor meltdown blowing away half a ship, everything demolished or processed incorrectly will be deducted from your already miserable pay, and also make you fail company Salvage Goals (more on them later). You‚Äôll have to learn how to properly disassemble many kinds of engines, machinery, reactors, and deal with mishaps on the fly before they become critical. There are even ships with rogue AIs on them, scrambling the internal systems randomly and making your life hell. Should you die, a heavy fine will be applied, but you‚Äôll respawn without penalties.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2826879455Progression SystemDepending on your performance in salvaging, you‚Äôll be credited Rank Points and Lynx Point Upon fulfilling salvage goals, which are milestones in correctly dismantling each ship - of course, more complex or hazardous ships will reward more of them. You may spend LPs to upgrade your initially pretty bad tools, making them more resilient, efficient, or even add new functions to them. Your passive gear can be enhanced as well, for instance sensors can be improved to detect more item types, while your suit can be reinforced to make you withstand even harsher conditions. Once in a while the story itself will go on, unlocking tutorial ships that will illustrate critical game mechanics or teach you how to use a new upgrade - but that‚Äôs not always the case: sometimes, especially later on, you‚Äôll have to figure things out on your own. Side Activities & CollectiblesThere are few things to do aside from shipbreaking, and they mostly relate to collecting. Posters found in wrecks can be taken, and used to customize your habitation pod. Stickers, awarded for progression milestones or particularly good performances, can be put onto tools as a cosmetic enhancement, but serve no other purpose. At some point a ‚Äòship repair‚Äô minigame will come up, allowing you to illegally salvage components that should go to LYNX for your own purposes. Decrypting and listening (or reading) lost data recording can be interesting, as it sheds light on the state of the galaxy, but it will take a huge amount of time to find them all.https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2826400964Additional Game ModesFree Play allows you to pick from any ship models, everything unlocked, to just have some fun either scrapping it correctly or blowing it to bits - sandbox no-consequence mode. Cutter‚Äôs RACE is sort of a time trial where you can compete against the clock to salvage a ship as fast - and as well - as humanly possible.

First release in 2020 for the PS4. Reinterpretation of the PS1 classic that only shows the first 8-hours of Final Fantasy VII and stretch into a 33-hours game. The real problem is that they made structure and story changes that destroyed the magic of the original. If you haven't played FFVII before, I recommend the 1997 version first. Note: The review is based on my Final Fantasy VII Remake playthrough on PS4 and a replay the the original FFVII (PS4 port - Midgar Part) in 2020. ‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†ÄMy curator page‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä‚†Ä

Another FromSoftware masterpiece which takes the ‚ÄûDark Souls DNA‚Äú and put it into an Action-adventure game.Positive(1) Great soundtrack especially at bossfights(2) Fast loading times(3) HDR support(4) Great visuals(5) Fixed difficulty setting (6) Very demanding Bossfights but never unfair (7) Native Xbox One Controller support. DUALSHOCK 4 also supported(8) Good enemy placement(9) Perfectly balanced progression system so you can't be overpowered(10) Superb fast combat and satisfying parry mechanic(11) Good level design but doesn't come up to the class of Dark Souls 1(12) Replayability because of New Game+ and different endings (new bosses)Negative(1) 60 fps lock(2) No ultrawide native support (only via mods)(3) Only one default main weapon and armorMY REVIEW SETUP:

First released in 1995 for the SNES and designed by the "Dream Team" Hironobu Sakaguchi (creator of Square's Final Fantasy series), Yuji  Horii (creator of Enix's Dragon Quest series) and Akira  Toriyama (creator of the Dragonball mangas). The Steam version is based on the mobile port. I played it for the first time in 2018 and it's amazing how well this game has aged. For me its: Still one of the best JRPG ever made.Positive Straight forward time travel story with great pacing and no filler Replayability because of different endings Active Time Battle (ATM) System with NO separate fighting screen and random encounters Superb soundtrack (composed by Yasunori Mitsuda and Nobuo Uematsu) Original graphic mode: "Similar to the original pixel art"  Fixed difficulty setting Native 16:9 support 4:3 support, to play it in fullscreen you have to change the system resolution to 4:3 Native Xbox One Controller support. DUALSHOCK 4 also supported Negative Modified mobile User Interface. No original SNES UI Partly custom controller binding. You could only change X, Y, B and A buttons The onscreen conroller buttons only shows the Xbox layout MY REVIEW SETUP: i7-6700K | 32 GB DDR4 | GTX 1080 FE | HDD install | Win 10 Pro | 
1920x1080 60 Hz | Controllers: Xbox1 + PS4 Wireless - My curator page

This is a very unique game with lots of features such as picking up items, climbing walls and the ability to change character at any time. The main character is a little girl named "Mary" and she fell asleep in a wardrobe after hiding from her parents arguing and now when she wakes up she discorvers that she is in an magical world full of giant strawberries and magical druids!. She has a friend called "Aquarius" and togheter they walk around in this world solving puzzles and quests trying to find a way back to the real world. It got great graphics.Pros:The game is cheap and you can get trading cards. The graphics are amazing The music is greatThe physics are 10/10The controls are easy to get used toCons: There is no menu or tutorial

What an awesome new way to experience Portal!Playing with the element of time, where what you do in the past affect the future, but what you do in the future does not affect the past. Kinda obvious but spooky when put into practical use.The levels could be very challenging if the concept isn't entirely understood, which makes it all the more fun and exciting to solve.I hope for new levels and more content like this!Community content taken to an official level, awesome stuff!

It was not mentioned that co-op is only with random people.Can't get a refund as I waited over 2 weeks to play with a friend.The game itself is amazing and I was very hyped towards the experience, but this weird decision to make it co-op only with strangers - makes it more a singleplayer game than an "online co-op" game.

I have no idea how, but it's even better than DOOM 2016.Epic carnage, blood, gore, weapons. Fast paced action all around.Story really gives you a reason to want to push through the hordes and move forward.A bunch of collectables with a great map that helps finding the general direction of the hidden item, but still leaving the search to the player.Saving is very limited, very specific auto-save checkpoints and end of missions.Forced me to leave the game open when I had to leave yet didn't want to lose progress.But whatever.All around a great experience, worth my money.

Very challenging but with the dedication that is required comes great satisfaction and fun.Dark Souls in Japanese, Katanas, Kiminos and other elements that indicate Asian culture.I loved the challenge and the thrill of facing an impossible boss again, and again, and again; and finally becoming so good you destroy that boss in a great attempt.Spent my weekends playing this while off the army, enjoyed the struggle and travel around the game.
Great fun, satisfying and fun with friends. Could be challenging at times, but youtube is always there to help you out. Great price. No regret in playing a mobile game on my GTX1080ti.

It might be short, but size doesn't matter. (Right?)An amazing experience, just diving into this world and exploring it, the way everything's done, satisfying, high quality.I'm not a game reviewer but I definitely should've played this earlier.What an amazing ride.

What an interesting experience!I very much enjoyed the beautiful sountrack the game has, the pixel art is simplistic and beatifully done!The actions you do and the way the world responds to you is often satisfying, ecouraging you to not procrastinate!The gameplay is simple: Build smart enough to protect what makes you coins so that you may either conquer the land and leave to the next or just leave to the next one. That's my way of seeing it ignoring the road getting to your purpose.The challenge of the game for me is in two things:1. Earning coins: It's not simple to establish a good source of coins, as you get attacked and caught off guard at times which destroys all your work, and rebuilding deep into the game is suicide as you will encounter more enemies as the days go by.2. NPC speed: The builders you hire and command, the beggers you give coin and reason to walk to your town, all WALK so SLOWLY!!! I can't count the amount of times I saw a begger I payed die because he walked so slowly towards the town.DAYS will pass by the time far away builders will finally come to your position and get what you need done. Of course they can die easily if you didn't plan ahead their position when the enemy's horde pummels through your walls.These 2 incredible challenges made me too frustrated to continue playing normally, so I get a Cheat Engie table for some "boosters" as god mode, infinitie coins, archers that shoot more arrows a second than there are trees in the entire game, and so on.To summerize:The game is made beautifully made and is challenging!So prepare yourself for some tough times, but maybe you'll like the struggle. The beautiful sountrack and design will help you through it all, so have at it at your own risk.The price is fair, so don't wait for a sale and support these great developers!

‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• what a ride!You might think that 13 hours is little, but every ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minute was fun.(I only finished the story, got lots of fun maps to explore with my friends!)Gameplay wise, it's too much fun.The variety of weapons and their uses, their mods and upgrades, makes it all awesome fun.Lots of blood and crazy animations. Movement is pretty simple for the most of it.The powerups that you can find are ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• AWESOME!The maps are full of interesting things to find and explore, adding more to the killings you do endlessly.Story wise, it's pretty good.While it's not Witcher 3-36-possible-endings-GOTY-tear-spawning-heart-crushing-love-making story,It's good enough to give you purpose and some things to think about. The characters are interesting and each with their own ideas and ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• whatever I like killing stuff.Personally it felt a bit slow at the start, but it was probably just to get new players used to the game.To summerize,It's an experience every gamer who thinks he likes FPS should try,an experience every gamer who thinks he likes to kill should try,an experience every gamer who thinks he like to have fun should try.Truely, a masterpiece.TL;DRSTOP WASTING YOUR TIME READING THIS AND ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• BUY IT IT'S ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• AWESOME

I'll never be able to describe the experience as a whole in words, the story and gameplay is just too much.The DLCs are amazing, price feels just right for the amount of content they add.I find this a very enjoyable game, beatifully made and written.Fighting is interesting although simple, the riddles are too much fun to solve,roaming the beautiful maps is amazing, listening to the music is exciting,and finishing the game is heartbreaking..I wish I had a meme or something to finish the review, but this game is worthy of much than that.I leave my heart here. The feelings the game awoke in me reside in this review.Feast on them, and know what a real game can make you feel.

Awesome gameplay, a damn shame it's peer2peer connection, dedicated servers would've made this a 5/5 trumps.I gives this 3 trumps out of five, damn connection is annoying when people are continents away from you.
